title: Human Capital Building in R&D - the Key to Enhanced Economic Competitiveness of SEE Economies
segmentation: Good morning everybody.
Thank you very much for giving me this chance.
I come from the Regional Cooperation Council which is.
Also mentioned it was mentioned amid yesterday.
It's a successor to the Stability Pact for Southeastern Europe.
And it's, uh, it has its headquarters in Sorio I'm not really sure how much you know about RCC, so I'll make a very brief outline of our major tasks and responsibilities.
And then I'd like to give you a flavor of some of the activities we do in cooperation with international partners and the governments of the region.
Related to the topic of this conference, so you know regional cooperation.
It started very early on with the Stability Pact, but we have inherited that mission at the RCC.
So we believe cooperation is a very important mechanism that contributes to the stabilization of the region and the integration into EU and NATO.
We're looking at at it at cooperation from two different perspectives from the political and from the.
Project related perspective.
So its intergovernmental framework.
It was the government of the region that got together heads of State decided to create RCC as their operational arm.
And it it's membership expands more than the region, so there are other countries that basically are involved in the.
You know in the board of RCC and they they contribute in different ways.

Very briefly, our major tasks to facilitate regional cooperation in Southeastern Europe to help or contribute to the acceleration of reforms in the region to support the commitments of the countries with respect to their eventual goals of you and your Atlantic integration, but then also from the other side, support the involvement of U and the donor community.
In
The region.

Some objectives of I'll maybe not mention all of them, but some of them yes are important, so we want to be an actor that contributes to the continued stability, security, mutual respect, and open dialogue in the region.
It's very important to rebrand the image of this region which has been damaged over the past.
Decades because of you know wars and conflicts.
And then as I said, we aim to act as an interlocutor and link between EU and the cooperation process of Southeastern Europe, especially with respect to project generation in the region.

And then we have created a very important link with the European Commission and there are multi beneficial instrument for pre accession funding that is basically very very closely linked with our institution and distributed mostly through our institutions simply because we have the regional.
The regional perspective in mind.
And then yes, in itself.
RCC represents the forum for dialogue where all the countries, international organizations and other interested partner scanner can sit together and discuss.
We're pretty new.
We were launched last year, but then we became fully operational about a year ago in May 2008.
We have a secretariat in Sarajevo.
We have liaison office in Brussels and we have about 30 people all.
Coming from the region.
Then to conclude with this part, with the RCC introduction.

We have a very broad focus of our activities, economic and social development is one of the priority areas and part of that unit energy and infrastructure, justice and Home Affairs, security cooperation and building human capital.
Of course there are other broader themes.
Cross cutting things, parliamentary cooperation, gender mainstreaming.
Social cohesion.
Civil society.
Up as they said, we're we're using very much our links with both the international partners and the governments of the region.
I wanted to bring an example of how we are making good use and of the information and the strategic guidance that.
Technical work being done by international organisations in cooperation with with us is feeding into, you know, the priority agenda for the region.
And one particular study is 1 conducted by the OECD.
Which is entitled defining strengthening sector specific sources of competitiveness in the Western Balkans, and that provides recommendations for a regional investment strategy.
This was supported by the European Commission and RCC, but OECD, of course provided the main technical expertise.
And it's looking at the sources and obstacles to competitiveness to increase competitiveness in the region.
Now the study found out that.
Basically, at the current stage, the region can only compete at the cost level, so it's only cost competitive.
So basically be cause labor costs are relatively lower than in many other regions.
We have that sort of competitiveness.
For instance, I just wanted to mention that.
You know the cost of Labor in the services sector.
For instance, it was calculated to be around five times lower than in Hungary or Poland, or the manufacturing sector.
The cost is again up to five times lower than Western Europe.
So basically I mean we can see where the competitive advantage of the region comes from.
But is that sustainable will not necessarily be cause in the recent past.
Labor costs have been increasing tremendously in the region, so much faster than any other region in the world.
And then of course there is pressure and competition from from the you know, Big Eastern countries of China and India, which are very very cost competitive as well.
And they can even make up for the, you know, for the distance and transport costs so.
So basically there is a real risk in the region in terms of, you know, sustaining their competitiveness.
So what needs to be done?
Some of the.
You know identified weakness is is that the first step you need to identify where the problem lies.
First and foremost, there are significant gaps in human capital.
What is produced and what is provided in terms of services has limited value.
Added and limited innovation.
There are obvious insufficient links between the research and the business community.
And then of course there are specific sectors that really were the focus should be really allocated where you know the the countries of the region would have a competitive.
Advantage eventually I'll mention that in a second.

So it's important of course, as I said, the first issue, human capital development, so it remains very important to really promote human capital development and one of the major recommendations is to try to align demand and supply of Labor, because there is a strong mismatch and discrepancy between.
You know what the demand is and what the countries of the region supply in terms of Labor, and this can of course very well work if there are.
You know coordination groups established even within each country but were different ministries sit together and discuss.
Discuss these issues.
Next, of course, foster research and innovation, and here it's very important to promote collaboration between firms, businesses, academia and of course research institutions.
And 3rd, I wanted to mention the specific sectors that were identified as.
Potentially competitive for the region and they are automotive sector, textile and garment information.
Communication technology and business process outsourcing.
Soap.
It's a, you know, it's basically.
But based on this research and in this study it's in these sectors that the attention of the region should be focused.

Very briefly mentioned, a couple of other events just to give you a flavor of what RCC is doing actually or other events that happened recently and you know how we are trying to help and and promote these initiatives.

It was also mentioned yesterday that you know the RCC has been involved in the coordination of activities towards the development of this draft project on the regional strategy for research and development for the Western Balkans.
And in that context, there was a of course ministerial conference.

It was also mentioned that was last month, but that was very important because it was, you know, strong participation and support from the European Commission, but also strong political will expressed by the countries themselves right?
And they came up with a joint statement that outlines future steps towards, you know the preparation of this regional strategy for research and development.
Not, of course, that remains very important because that would help all the countries join, join their efforts in the you know, research strategy.
But then, of course, it's also very important the exchange of information and knowledge and.
You know and best practice.
And yes, I mean the countries have agreed that they would need to develop a clear road map that they will follow towards the preparation of this regional research strategy.
It's still at the beginning.
However there is, you know, strong support from all sides so.
She will obviously be really involved and supportive of it.
End.
One more thing, it's.
Our support to the cooperation on climate change, which basically it's.
It's also very relevant in the current situation, so RCC has cooperated in establishing a road map for Environmental Corporation in Southeastern Europe and it's Co organizing many different events.
That of course raise raise awareness.
But also, you know, make the links between the different countries.
Um?

A while ago we also organized the Ministerial Conference on Climate Change on combatting climate Change in Sarajevo and they came up of course with the Joint Ministerial statement and you know, climate Change action plan for adaptation was was approved.

This remains very important because if you take into account that Southeast Europe is very, very vulnerable, vulnerable to climate change, you know activities on the adaptation to climate change are recognized as crucial for the region, and then of course our species there to also provide the link and the connection with the with the donor community.

I wanted to send the ended adaptation measures need to be supported by mitigation measures and this all needs to have them in the context of this conference needs to have a, you know, scientific approach if you want to cope with these issues, you need to be innovative and.
And be as competitive as possible.
I'll maybe.

I mean, there are a lot of things I could talk about that we're doing, because basically in all the five priority areas you know being being competitive, being innovative is is is the base that we are strongly supporting and pushing in every in every direction.
So I'll stop here.
And if you have any questions, maybe you.
Mask.
And then of course, we'll maybe have more chance to talk later if you're interested in specific issues or sectors.

Thank you very much for this insight into this regional cooperation aspect, and perhaps I would like to add that we are operating hours are sort of brand and original Corporation counsel on preparation of a workshop on the 10th of June about the utilization of human capital of scientific diaspora.
Countries with the use of ice, did you know?
But if he approaches, so if somebody is interested in this, very comment will be at the premises of Regional Cooperation Council One Day workshop by Austrian Federal Ministry of Science and Research.
At any questions please.
What was that in dealing with both incoming public capital didn't even mention Task force on building and fostering human capital, which is supposed to save the link.
Education isn't research sex toy and I think coming back for conferences in the in the March will also be conferencing in Bucharest.
Becausw the passport now is chaired by Romain.
And.
Quite.
Touch.
Well, I mean you are right.
But basically what I what I wanted to emphasize is the you know, the research and development aspects of what we're doing and the competitiveness.
I mean we.
There are basically more than 20 task forces and initiatives, but.
Excuse me up.
It's it's a.
It's a combination.

Actually the European Commission is providing part of the budget, but then it's a it's the countries of the region that themselves you know, in the spirit of regional ownership and cooperation they provide part of it as well.
So all the countries of South Eastern Europe.
What's the magic?
What?
Well, actually, I mean the funding is it actually has three parts, so it's it's European Commission.
It's donor countries and its countries of the region.
Total budget is about 3 million.
Euros in each.
Each part has 1/3, so basically.
1 million from the Commission, 1 million from the countries of the region and each count.
I mean, there is a formula.
Each country depending on you know because of different sizes.
They have different contributions.
There is a formula for that.
But it's important that all the countries are really contributing.
Well, we're we're presenting projects.
Do I actually projects of regional importance?
Because quite often you know countries themselves, they have the national perspective and the.
I mean not to judge them, but sometimes you know RCC would have a better regional perspective.

So basically what we've done recently is to submit to WIFU several project proposals that we have consulted with the countries of the region, got their approval, but since we're also project oriented, we have we're submitting a list of projects for financing at the regional level, yeah?

I mean, we don't have just to work through that we don't have, you know, technical capacity to manage, but you know we we provide value added in in the preparation of projects simply because we have the.
The regional perspective and overview.
Thank you very much.
